abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the States' Road
            Infrastructure Development Technical Assistance Project for
            India is rated satisfactory. The main objective was
            achieved. Sixteen states ended up meeting entry conditions
            and became participants in the project, compared to fifteen
            potential candidate states identified at appraisal.
            Activities related to institutional development were carried
            out, but they were intended to help prepare institutional
            development changes rather than carry out reforms. A key
            indicator of the project's sustainability is the
            satisfactory progress, with just minor exceptions, in the
            implementation of the several follow-on state road projects
            that were originated by the technical assistance (TA)
            project. The following lessons were learned: The risks of
            multi-state projects should be carefully assessed during
            preparation, especially due to the greater complexity of
            supervision required. Entry conditions requiring commitment
            to reforms are useful when such commitments are formalized
            vis-a-vis of both the central government and the Bank.
            Resettlement and rehabilitation policies are an issue which
            can cause conflict especially in states which are confronted
            with Bank regulations for the first time.
